name: certificate
content:
certificate

noun
 
 
/səˈtɪfɪkət/
 
/sərˈtɪfɪkət/
(abbreviation cert.)
jump to other results
  1.  
    an official document that may be used to prove that the facts it states are true
    • a birth/marriage/death certificate
    • certificate of something a certificate of motor insurance
    see also digital certificate, film certificate, gift certificate, X certificate
    Extra Examples
    • The police are waiting for the doctor to issue a death certificate.
    • a certificate of authenticity
    • She showed her certificate of insurance.
    • Everyone entering the country needs to show a health certificate.
    • This certificate is an important document. Keep it in a safe place.
    Topics Life stagesb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • birth
    • death
    • marriage
    • …
    verb + certificate
    • award (somebody)
    • issue
    • earn
    • …
    preposition
    • certificate of
    See full entry
  2.  
    an official document proving that you have completed a course of study or passed an exam; a qualification obtained after a course of study or an exam
    • a Postgraduate Certificate in Education (= a British qualification for teachers)
    • certificate of something A certificate of completion will be issued to all who complete the course.
    Topics Successb2, Educationb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • birth
    • death
    • marriage
    • …
    verb + certificate
    • award (somebody)
    • issue
    • earn
    • …
    preposition
    • certificate of
    See full entry
    3. Word Originlate Middle English (in the sense ‘certification’): from French certificat or medieval Latin certificatum, from certificare, from Latin certus ‘certain’.

/səˈtɪfɪkeɪts/
 
/sərˈtɪfɪkeɪts/

name: X certificate
content:
X certificate

 
/ˈeks sətɪfɪkət/
 
/ˈeks sərtɪfɪkət/
jump to other results
  1. a label that was given in the past to certain cinema films in Britain by the British Board of Film Censors (now called the British Board of Film Classification). Films were given an X certificate if they were not considered to be suitable for people under 18, usually because they contained violence, sex or bad language. In 1982 the label 'X certificate' was changed to '18’.
Check pronunciation: X certificate

name: film certificate
content:
film certificate

noun
 
/ˈfɪlm sətɪfɪkət/
 
/ˈfɪlm sərtɪfɪkət/
(British English)
(North American English movie rating
 
/ˈmuːvi reɪtɪŋ/
 
/ˈmuːvi reɪtɪŋ/
)
jump to other results
  1. a label that is put on films, stating who should be allowed to watch or download them
    CultureIn Britain, the British Board of Film Classification places films in one of five groups, U (Universal) for films which can be seen by anybody, PG (Parental Guidance) for films which may upset young children, 12A for films where a child under 12 should be with an adult, 15 where no one under 15 should see the film, and 18, which is considered only suitable for adults. The label R18 means that the film can only be shown in cinemas that have a licence, or the DVD bought in sex shops that have a licence. Websites offering the film for download must check the age of the user. The label 12 is only for DVDs and downloads, to show that they are considered suitable for children aged 12 and above.In the US, a film is given one of five labels by the Classification and Rating Administration of the Motion Picture Association of America. These are: G for general audiences, PG for parental guidance (meaning that parents decide whether to let their children see the film), PG-13 for parental guidance for children under 13, R for restricted (which means that children under 17 should only see the film with a parent or other adult who is responsible for them), and NC-17 (no one 17 and under) for films which may only be seen by adults.
Check pronunciation: film certificate

gift certificate

noun
 
/ˈɡɪft sətɪfɪkət/
 
/ˈɡɪft sərtɪfɪkət/

name: digital certificate
content:
digital certificate

noun
 
/ˌdɪdʒɪtl səˈtɪfɪkət/
 
/ˌdɪdʒɪtl sərˈtɪfɪkət/
(computing)
jump to other results
  1. an electronic document that is used to prove the identity of a website and ensure that it is safe to use

    • Digital certificates have become valuable targets for cybercriminals.

name: General Certificate of Education
content:
General Certificate of Education

noun
 
/ˌdʒenrəl səˌtɪfɪkət əv edʒuˈkeɪʃn/
 
/ˌdʒenrəl sərˌtɪfɪkət əv edʒuˈkeɪʃn/
(abbreviation GCE)
jump to other results
  1. a British exam taken by students in England and Wales and some other countries in any of a range of subjects. GCE O levels were replaced in 1988 by GCSE exams. GCE A levels are still the main exams taken in England and Wales at age 18.
Check pronunciation: General Certificate of Education

/ˌdʒenrəl sərˌtɪfɪkət əv ˌsekənderi edʒuˈkeɪʃn/
(abbreviation GCSE)
jump to other results
  1. a British exam taken by students in England and Wales and some other countries, usually around the age of 16. GCSEs can be taken in any of a range of subjects.

General Certificate of Secondary Education noun

name: the Scottish Certificate of Education
content:
the Scottish Certificate of Education

noun
 
/ðə ˌskɒtɪʃ səˌtɪfɪkət əv edʒuˈkeɪʃn/
 
/ðə ˌskɑːtɪʃ sərˌtɪfɪkət əv edʒuˈkeɪʃn/
jump to other results
  1. a former set of examinations and qualifications in Scottish schools. The Standard Grade of the examination was taken at the age of 16 and was equivalent to GCSE in England and Wales. The Higher grade was taken at the age of 17.
Check pronunciation: the Scottish Certificate of Education
nearBys: the Scottish Certificate of Education noun
